handDesc.p: Halantas. Final N in line 21 is essentially identical to a na, raised above normal height.

Other palaeographic observations. Anusvāra is above the character to which it belongs, or above headline to the right of that character; occasionally atop the next character, e.g. l13 kuṭuṁbinaḥ within the i marker. Short and long i/ī are not clearly distinguishable, but i seems to be a closed circle while ī appears to be open on the left, with a little hook at the opening; e.g. sti and śrī side by side in line 1; śī in line 5 is good example of the long ī. Headmarks are large horizontal lines with small horns on each side.

div.head: Plates
div.p:

navya-sagotrāṇāṁ harīti-putrāṇāṁ kauśikī-vara-prasāda-la
bdha-raājyānāṁ rmmamātr̥-gaṇa-paripaālitānāṁ svaāmi-mahā
sena-paādaānudhyaātānāṁ bhagavan-nārāyaṇa-prasāda-sa
māsādita-vara-varāha-lāñcchanekṣaṇa-kṣaṇa-vaśīkr̥
tārāti-maṇḍalānaām aśvamedhaāvabhr̥tha-snāna-pavitrīkr̥

merur iva śaṁsita-mitrodayaḥ ṇaggiḥ vārātībhitī-kr̥ta
-cakraḥ jalanidhir iva lakṣmī-prabhavaḥ vijayāditya-mahārā
jādhirāja-parameśvara-bhaṭṭaārakaḥ gudravara-viṣeaya-vaāsinao

ti

viditam astu vo ’smaābhir dvaija-vrir̥ndārakaḥsya krova
śiri-vāstavyāya kuppaśarmmaṇaḥ pautrāya śarvvaśarmmaṇaḥ pu

-bīja-vāpa-pramāṇaṁ kṣetraṁ pradattaṁ

tasyāvadhayaḥ. pūrvvataḥ kappa

app.note: The vowel of ḷ may be ū, or the engraver may have started engraving ḷya and then corrected.

There is little damage here; in fact the most damaged part of this locus is the last three characters, of whose reading I am quite certain. The preceding characters, however, are ambiguous on account of the script and the execution, and I am unable to offer a satisfactory reading. It is likely that multiple scribal errors are involved in addition to the ambiguous characters. The first problematic character, read as ṇa, might well be nā or vā, and reading ya or śā is not out of the question. The second definitely looks like ggi, but either of its consonant components may perhaps be dh instead of g. This is probably followed by a visarga, but it is just possible that this is instead a vowel marker (for e or part of o) attached to the next character. The third character looks much, but not entirely, like the first, so all possibilities listed for that also apply here, with the added complication that there may be a vowel marker prefixed to this character. This is definitely followed by rā, and the next two characters resemble one another, but are not identical. I read the consonant of the first as t, because this is the only way I can account for what looks like a notch in the upper outline of its body, which I take to be the hook of t. However, its shape in general looks more like bh, ś or n, less probably v or c. The second of the two similar characters is most likely bhī, but śī and nī are also possible. Any of the i-s in this stretch may be either short or long; I read long ī where the loop is open on the left, but this may be random variation. The closest to an intelligible phrase that I can obtain from the text is vāri-rāśi-śītīkr̥ta (assuming scribal omission of ri), but I have no inkling what ṇaggiḥ may be. I would expect this phrase to resemble the preceding and following qualifier, and thus to include a simile with iva and a double entendre. The double entendre may perhaps be that Vijayāditya's army (cakra) is “cooled” (i.e., its martial ardour is diminished) only when it reaches the ocean; in this, he may be compared to the moon (?), whose orbit (cakra) is cooled by water and by the signs of the zodiac - but this is probably just my forced attempt to make sense of the text. There is also a possibility that the end of this locus should be read śitīkr̥ta (perhaps with a play on “sharpened discus” and “brightened domain”); or that ivārāti (perhaps with wordplay involving “enemy” and “not favour”) is to be read in the middle of this chunk. Related grants offer no better clue; the only comparable expressions involving cakra that I am aware of are cakradhara Ivāpratihata-cakraḥ in the Peṇukapaṟu grant of Jayasiṁha I and viṣṇor iva sva-cakra-nandakasya in the Koṟṟapaṟṟu grant of Vijayāditya II.
The ARIE report gives the father's name as Bandhuśarman. While the initial śa is not unambiguously drawn, ndhu can be safely excluded. Compare rvva in line 13 and especially line 18.

The ARIE report records the name of the village as Maṅgaveḍu. There is definitely no ṅ here, though an anusvāra may be present. The vertical vowel marker between g and v in my opinion bends to the left at the top, and is thus probably associated with g rather than with the next character.

div.head: Plates
div.p: Greetings. The dear son of His Majesty King mahārāja Viṣṇuvardhana IV or VI do not know of any other Eastern Cālukya grant that mentions the reigning king’s father before his grandfather. It seems likely that starting out with Viṣṇuvardhana is a mistake in the composition, which was corrected by adding Vijayāditya afterward. This may have been simple oversight, or perhaps the text of the charter was based on a grant of the king’s father (Viṣṇuvardhana IV or V), which would have mentioned the grandfather (Viṣṇuvardhana III or IV) first. The composer of the present charter may have mechanically reproduced Viṣṇuvardhana here, and then changed the wording to make him the father of the present king. who attained victory in the clash of many a battle and who was eager to adorn the lineage of the majestic Caḷukyas—who are of the Mānavya gotra which is praised by the entire world, who are sons of Harīti, who attained kingship by the grace of Kauśikī’s boon, who are protected by the band of Mothers, who were deliberately appointed to kingship by Lord Mahāsena, to whom the realms of adversaries instantaneously submit at the mere sight of the superior Boar emblem they have acquired by the grace of the divine Nārāyaṇa, and whose bodies have been hallowed through washing in the purificatory ablutions avabhr̥tha of the Aśvamedha sacrifice—; grandson of King mahārāja Vijayāditya I or II; namely the Supreme Lord parameśvara of Emperors mahārājādhirāja and Supreme Sovereign parama-bhaṭṭāraka Vijayāditya II or III—who desires the exaltation of his allies as Mount Meru which indicates the rising of the sun; whose circle domain is made See the apparatus to line 10 for some thoughts on the phrase that I am unable to interpret here.; and who gives rise to prosperity as the ocean produced Lakṣmī—commands all householders kuṭumbin—including foremost the overseers kūṭaka— who reside in Gudravara district viṣaya as follows:

Let it be known to you that to Yajñaśarman of the Bhāradvāja gotra and the Āpastambha sūtra—a resident of Krovaśiri who has studied the Veda, and who is the grandson of Kuppaśarman, a principal of the twiceborn,The composer’s intent may have been to describe the donee, rather than the grandfather, as a principal of the twiceborn. and son of Śarvaśarman—we have given a field of an extent sufficient for sowing ten kaṇḍikas of paddy seed at the village named Magāvaḍu.

Its boundaries are as follows. To the east, the Kappani field cenu. To the south, the Ceṟukani field cenu. To the west, the Goduna Boḍu field cenu. To the north, the Rājāḍi field cenu. It is situated in the midst of these boundaries.
Over and over again, Rāmabhadra begs all future kings thus: “Each in your own time, you shall respect this framework of legality that is universally applicable to kings!”

The ARIE report reads the name of the donated village as Maṁgaveḍu, and identifies it with modern Maṅginapūḍi in Bandar taluk of Kistna district. The reading seems doubtful to me, and I therefore prefer to name the charter after its findspot. The report identifies Krovaśiri with modern Krōsūru in Sattenapalle taluk of Guntur district. Several donees hailing from Krovaśiri are also mentioned in the Koṟṟapaṟṟu grant of Vijayāditya II (none of them are of the Bhāradvāja gotra).

The ARIE report further states that the ājñapti of the grant is Paṇḍaraṅga, “the bee at the lotus-feet of Guṇagāṅka-Vijayāditya.” Neither the name nor the description appear anywhere in the photos available online. The photos include one blank face, which is probably 1 recto, so it is possible that a description of the executor (perhaps an anuṣṭubh stanza) was written on 3 verso, of which no photo has been published.

Reported in 7A/1938-392 with discussion at 71-724. Although the report says an edition was to be published in Epigraphia Indica, this does not appear to have happened. I know of no published edition of these plates. The present edition has been prepared for DHARMA by Dániel Balogh on the basis of photos published by the Indian Museum (Kolkata).http://museumsofindia.gov.in/repository/record/im_kol-11358-19. The photos show the seal, four inscribed faces and one blank face. The sixth face may not be blank; see the commentary.
